Colin and Ken Lloyd:  I figured that the solution was something along those=
 lines, I just do not know what track NEAT takes.  I have read some of the =
papers such as the co-evolution paper with robots, but could not find any d=
etails about this.

I am trying to write a neural network library and want =
to make sure I will eventually be able to implement NEAT easily. (and Hyper=
NEAT et al.) 

Tom

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken Lloyd" <kalloyd@...> =
wrote:
>
> The pattern that appears at the outputs is under-determined when=
 there are
> recurrent cycles.  You can wait (but you don't know how long, =
as in Colin's
> fixed number of iterations), or use an in-recurrence flag o=
r token.  Greedy
> BFS, Dijkstra, or Bellman-Ford can be used to identify r=
ecurrent cycles.
>  
> Ken Lloyd
> 
>

> > I haven't f=
ound the method by which NEAT resolves recurrent structures. A
> quick poin=
t in the
> > right direction would be helpful.
> >
> 
> Not sure if this is=
 what you mean but the evolved networks that are
> recurrent aren't resolve=
d in any way at all. What happens is that an
> activation scheme is require=
d to use them, some simple schemes would
> be:
> 
> A) Activate for some fi=
xed number of iterations.
> B) Activate until the network is relaxed. E.g. =
until the change in
> output value of all nodes is within some threshold.
>=
 C) (A) but with the fixed number of activations determined by
> analysing =
the network and calculating its maximum depth, such that we
> can get at le=
ast some signals all the way from the input nodes to the
> outputs.
> 
> Co=
lin
>
